criticReviews.criticPost: I'm not ashamed to say I stood and clapped at the end, on my own in a quiet room.
If the plot had been at all predictable, this melange of styles could have been self-indulgent. But the story kept surprising us.
The results are harrowing, hilarious and genre-busting.
Baynton and Corden play off one another very well, giving The Wrong Mans a nice comedic center that's surrounded by nutty plot developments and occasional, surprisingly dark subject matter.
There are times when the series' many twists can be hard to keep track of, but the show's whip-fast pacing is also one of its greatest assets.
It's never dull and frequently very funny.
Just as the weather turns rotten, here's The Wrong Mans, a bit of fun with a smart enough script and some actual jokes.
The goings-on feel fresh in the way that kids at play make spy or space stories their own, even as they repeat what TV and the movies have taught them.
It may not have the sharpness of a Wright effort, but the show is deeply committed to its world-colliding premise, and trots out a host of serious actors.

It certainly looks as good as a Hollywood thriller. It's only a shame that the combination of ordinary blokes and extraordinary setting won't feel original to anyone who's seen Shaun of the Dead or any other Simon Pegg/Nick Frost collaboration.
A comedy thriller that's too silly to be thrilling and not funny enough to be funny.
A geeky office worker picks up a ringing telephone at the scene of a car crash and sets in motion a crazy-funny mystery.
The Wrong Mans, Hulu's latest original series, is almost certainly the first Hitchcockian thriller sitcom that doubles as a critique of the global security state.

The series' absurdly complex plot and genre clichï¿½s are clearly tongue-in-cheek, but we still find ourselves rooting for the heroes and getting caught up in the suspense. Light and witty, the series is the perfect time filler.
Just as adept with suspense as slapstick humor, it's both a piss-take of action dramas and a strong action drama in its own right.
Average Joes get pulled into violence, accidental espionage.
Zoom: Off to the conspiracy-thriller races.
A comedy with a cinematic heart and two talented actors/writers at its core. We couldn't ask for more, aside from maybe a breathtaking train scene (oh wait, it has one of those too).
Corden and Baynton bring considerable charm to their broadly drawn roles, and have the natural rapport necessary for any odd couple pairing.

There are real stakes - Sam and Phil witness a number of violent deaths - a coherent mystery that makes sense by the end, and a propulsive narrative style that pushes our misfit heroes from one problem to the next to the next.
Give James Corden the right material, and he can make anything funny. He demonstrates this repeatedly in The Wrong Mans, his new spy-comedy series for the BBC and Hulu.
A (sort of) oldie but an oft-ignored goodie. Krysten Ritter (Jessica Jones) is at her acerbically funny best as the titular b**** in apartment 23.
Still funny and still an acquired taste.
This show only occasionally works, and I increasingly think it would have been a better bet as an animated show.
It's the same uneven show [as it was in season 1], full of ideas that seem funny in concept but only occasionally get there in execution.
It's a fun episode; Van Der Beek's good-sported spoofing of his past is still the best thing about the show.
The deliciously depraved sitcom, which returns for its second season tonight, reminds viewers that these days a working stiff can't catch a break.
I'm still not convinced this show can maintain its high degree of snark every single week but it's off to a more promising start than it was a year ago.
I'm still so impressed with how much Krysten Ritter can do with just her eyes.
It has a delightful bad attitude, a serrated insouciance.
[Ritter's] a breezy blast as pure, unrestrained id, and she's surrounded by a fine cast.
Raunchy and at times genuinely funny, Apartment 23 is jam-packed with promise - and inconsistencies.
The show offers dark, absurdest comedy that's refreshing, different, weird and totally worth watching.
One of the funniest of the new batch of female-centric comedies, with a fine supporting cast.
Strong ensemble, wit and James Van Der Beek as BFF make this one to watch.
One of the funnier network shows of the season.
Something happening in and around Apartment 23 ought to make you laugh.
Unlike some of the more uneven odd-couple series that have premiered in recent years, Apartment 23 could turn into a trustworthy address for laughs.
This tart and tangy comedy earns its attitude.
Some viewers will take offense at the title and the show's ribald humor, but the program holds appeal for fans of comedy that depends on pop-culture knowledge.
A deliciously nasty comedy that takes a well-worn formula and whips it to life with clever writing and an engaging cast.
While the show generally maneuvers well, it occasionally stumbles.
This bitch has got some pop.
The girls are perfect and the addition of James Van Der Beek playing himself is just hilarious.
Funny enough to overlook its spurious reason for existence and unpredictable enough to keep things from stagnating
You can trust that this B- is pretty d- funny.
It's intriguing for how it balances sweetness and sleaze.
Gets a reasonable amount of comedy out of this sturdy odd-couple setup.
That isn't to say the show lacks charm, only that its irreverence and madcap energy disguises a conventional mismatched buddy comedy.
I found that, no matter what stage the friendship was in, I didn't laugh out loud all that much at any of the episodes, though I was pleased overall by the leads and surreal worldview.
The new Romans are no replacement for the original Romans of the series.
It's all a muddled mess of computer-generated battlefield scenes.
The series finale justifies this last season's subtitle, War of the Damned, with a truly epic clash of historic titans.
The battle scenes make 300 seem like a Nickelodeon cartoon.
Beautifully filmed, engagingly good and filled with the most gorgeous men on TV.

It becomes clear why this final season is labeled War of the Damned, and all but guarantees that while [the] fighting will lead to a bitter end, it will lead viewers to the most savory of conclusions.
It's hard not to admire its improved quality and heightened sense of purpose.
Thus is the genius of Spartacus as a whole, to take what it would dub "grand spectacle" and reduce it to a two-person scene in which two hardened individuals lay themselves emotionally bare.
Ah, Spartacus! How much we've missed you.

Here at the Bureau for Solving Problems That May or May Not Be Problems, we have been on high alert all week because of the impending premiere of yet another installment of perhaps the most vile series on television, Spartacus.
It's cartoon violence, but it still creates enough blood spurt and spatter that we half expect to find we've stumbled into a crossover episode with "Dexter."
Spartacus in fact is what it is - a broadly drawn, visceral feast of blood, guts, lust and lower-rung language. War of the Damned doesn't spare any of it en route to its no doubt hellish conclusion.
Judging by the premiere, I get the sense this season will be every bit as good as the previous two.
Well written and acted, almost perfectly paced, and entirely unlike anything else on television, Spartacus isn't just bloody good, it's bloody excellent.
Everything fans loved about the first season is here. Everyone is not.
For the most part, the reincarnation works
The show keeps you on your toes.

With overripe dialogue that sounds like Shakespeare ground through a blender of baroque profanity, punctuated by action sequences of almost comical brutality amid orgies of debauchery, Spartacus is back with a vengeance.
The producers appear to have jacked up the violence and depravity even further.
No matter the casting changes, Spartacus remains good, dirty fun.
Spartacus just doesn't feel like it's going to have a long, happy life
Andinsofar as the show contributes to loosening standards and deadening the senses, that bloody victory over the cultural scolds might just be Spartacus most enduring form of revenge.
With such thin stories each week, it's small wonder that sex and violence are used to take up the slack.
This might prove to be the not-at-all-guilty pleasure of the season.

The poetic and evocative dialogue works, amazingly enough (it's almost Shakespearean at times), and as the world of Spartacus is fleshed out (in more ways than one), the show develops momentum and the intrigues become more interesting.
Spartacus is a rousing, addictive show that doesn't tax with too much moral complexity.
If the show's concerns do not rise far above the level of pulp -- and there is nothing wrong with that -- it does what it does with a sure hand.
If this isn't your cup of blood, give it a shot anyway.
Oh, this Spartacus. It's deliciously, marvelously bad, and I was helpless in its grip.
Although some characters share the same names as those in the 1960 Kirk Douglas movie of the same name, this vivid, revealing remake is not for the faint of heart.
If Stanley Kubrick were still alive - he directed the 1960 Kirk Douglas classic of the same name - he wouldn't know whether to laugh or weep.
The problem is that this Spartacus is so over the top that it begs to be considered as total camp.
A heady mix of 300-style graphic violence and Debbie Does Rome soft-core porn, Spartacus: Blood and Sand is proof of TV's ever-expanding boundaries and ever-plummeting tastes.
The trappings up front are so over the top that to say you watch Spartacus to see a contemporary reworking of a cinema classic is like saying you go to Hooters for the food.
Indeed, when the smoke clears from this blood-splattered battle, the survivors will likely stand and sheepishly plead, "I'm not 'Spartacus!' Please, don't confuse me with 'Spartacus!'"
It was written either by master satirists hoping to inspire viewer drinking games each time blood drops sail in slo-mo or by teen boys.
Not even my affection for honorary TCA member Lucy Lawless is going to keep me around.

Imagine watching a boring porn movie with swords, sandals, CGI, buckets and buckets of blood, and excessive slow-motion "action" scenes, all while Satan pulls your soul out of your backside. That's Spartacus: Blood and Sand.
